To preorder IMMUNE click here: https://kgs.link/ImmuneBook – Its available in English and German and on amazon it should be available in pretty much all countries too.
Ohai! I’m Philipp, the founder and head writer of Kurzgesagt and author of IMMUNE! Let me say a few words about it: IMMUNE is older than Kurzgesagt and I began working on it about a decade ago in university. The idea was to explore a super important but also extremely misunderstood and complicated topic and “translate” it into a language everybody could understand. I’ve done my best to basically write a super long Kurzgesagt video but with less of the limitations of a ten minute video.
IMMUNE is a fascinating and fun journey through your own body, together we’ll be exploring mystery organs, murder universities, your enemies from viruses, bacteria and cancer (and how your immune system might have killed a cancer cell while you were reading the last few sentences) and the incredibly beautiful and amazing parts, cells and systems that keep you alive. After reading it you should not only gain a new appreciation for your own body but also experience disease differently. A flu or something more serious will not be this abstract thing but something you can sort of witness and imagine which mechanisms are active and which cells are doing what. At least personally, knowing how the immune system works always has given me great comfort when I felt unwell. Also 45 illustrated pages by the Kurzgesagt team make the book very pretty.
Preorders are incredibly important in the world of books so if you are considering getting it, it would mean a lot if you could do that. Because preorders determine if a publisher will try to get the book into bookstores, so a lot of the book’s success depends on it.
I’m incredibly grateful that so many of you have watched these videos in the last few years. And I hope you will give my first book a chance too. – Philipp

The Immune System is a very controversial topic, as it is a very powerful tool, both literary and figuratively.
It causes concern over whether or not you need to get a certain vaccine, it is so complicated that only experts can talk about it without using it as a weapon. In politics, you can strike fear in the people by saying that their Immune System is failing them and to get a vaccine, while since they only know “oh, I am better, I’m not sick anymore! That means that I won’t get it since I’m immune!” Complete control over mindlessness. But this book has the power to change that and spread more truthful information to the people. It is truly amazing. Have read it myself, and it absolute perfection. Thank you so much for your work, and I hope that you make more books like this on such varying topics. Thank you, Kurzgesagt.

I recently finished this book and I totaly recomend it.
But although I am now more educated in how our immune system works, I got some questions about some counter intiutive parts of immune system.
For example - The things that we feel when we are sick (chillness, fever, tiredness, etd..) they are "signals" that our imune system is currently working on eradicating infection.
Another thing said in this book was about MHC-II proteins which are supposed to carry antigens of the pathogen that infected us. Also it was said that the reason why some people handles Covid better than others is the fact, that MHC-II proteins has greater genetic variability between different people, so that means that some people handles Covid (and probably other diseases) than others. So.. Does this mean that if I feel "more sick" than others, does this mean that my MHC-II protein works for sars-cov2 especially well and that actually my imune system is able to recognise this pathogen more effectively?
Long story short (in general): Worse symtpoms = better immune reaction againist particular pathogen?

Philipp Dettmer is the founder and head writer of Kurzgesagt, one of the largest science channels on YouTube, with over fourteen million subscribers and one billion views. After dropping out of high school at age fifteen, Dettmer met a remarkable teacher who inspired in him a passion for learning and understanding the world. He went on to study history and information design with a focus on infographics. After college, Dettmer started Kurzgesagt as a passion project to explain complicated ideas from a holistic perspective. When the channel took off, he dedicated himself full-time to making difficult ideas engaging and accessible.

So this thing popped on my mind I thought this would be useful for you guys

A leveling system for a post-scarcity society

Let's level a post-scarcity society as Three

Level 1 post-scarcity society: a society that can supply essential assistance and goods to the people( a society without the fear of next day food and shelter and other essential things)

Level 2 post-scarcity society: a society that can give benefit to the people more than essential needs (doing things more than just food like giving every individual a car)

Level3 post-scarcity society: a society that can fulfill all the desires of its people (I think virtual worlds and simulations are the best approach to it rather than actually making every little thing though )

Whatever caused basic cells to collaborate with each other and eventually form complex life forms on Earth wouldn't have been possible without the collaborative task of defense.  Nothing and I mean nothing of any cellular complexity would be here if cells didn't evolve to defend themselves from the vast array of other microscopic organisms on the planet.  The immune system is overlooked and taken for granted immensely.

This channel reminds me why I began studying science in the first place. When I'm drowning in work to learn new species and their particulars and how they contribute to an ever evolving ecosystem, when I'm breaking down body systems into organs for different marine creatures, when I have to memorize a seemingly never ending series of cells, I feel defeated, I don't see a point to it all. And then i take a break and watch Kurzgesagt and I'm reminded how beautiful and important the things I study are, and I feel a bit better. Thank you guys for the amazing, accurate and accessible work you do. You keep aspiring scientists like me motivated.

Dear Mr. Dettmer, I thank you for this wonderful book, and ask if this could be the first in a series. There are a lot of things that can and do go wrong in the body, and I think that people would like to understand the what and why of these processes so to make judgements based on accurate information.

For example, I possess ADHD. How does the human attention system work, and how does ADHD differ from this system? A lot of people notice that ADHD, Dyslexia/Dyscalculia/Dysgraphia, Non-verbal Learning Disorder, Major and Minor Depression, Autism, and Anxiety seem interrelated. How can such discrete conditions be so interrelated? Many people disbelieve in learning disorders, or treat learning disorders as a kind of a chronically bad choice may by the disabled. Others claim that learning disorders should qualify a person for disability benefits because of the learning disabled's difficulty in achieving the ability to thrive as an adult. Which is right?

This is not even getting into gender identity and human sexuality. In the first days of life, an embryo doesn't have a gender. It has blueprints that specify a gender, and so it tries to follow those blueprints. But gender is a complicated thing. It takes a cascade of hormones to turn an embryo female. It takes an entirely separate cascade of hormones as an interrupt to the first cascade to make a male. It is conceivable that an error-of-sequence can create someone borne as one sex liking the same sex, or separately, identifying as the opposite sex.

But then, it is plausible that a combination of social and mental factors, too many and to society-dependent to list, that yield the same result. Which is right? Are both right? I can't tell, that's why I ask. As a voter I'm called to make policy, in my small but real fraction of the franchise. To make that policy I need to understand what I'm trying to judge, or else I'm likely to hurt someone trying to follow my gut instinct.

I'm sorry to take up your time, thank you again for your wonderful body of work. May God bless you and yours.

As a medical student being asked a lot of questions (by family and friends ) regarding our immune system, vaccines and infections; I can say it’s definitely the most important system to teach simplistically to the public.

On a personal note your story really touched me because it reminds me of my romance with my immune system. Early onset systemic automatically, signs of immunodeficiency, some allergies, and a type of Lymphoma arising at age 15.
I fell in love with that system and after studying about it for so long I truly see sickness differently. When I get sick I imagine proliferation of B2 cells in the Germinal centers of the enlarged lymph nodes, during an allergic reaction I see degranulation of mast cells, and when I have an autoimmune flare I can see CD8 cells causing normal cells to go under apoptosis.
I chose to study Medicine (and research MD-PhD) and I definitely going to transition my romance with the immune system into a professional one. Either I become an oncologist or a clinical immunologist I’ll keep studying the immune system in health and disease, hoping to make a difference in scientific understanding and in people’s life.

Thank you for that book, I’ll definitely buy it, add it to my collection of immunology books (Janeway, Abbas, steighm, Midelton, Hochberg …. And the list just goes on)
